title: Isolated Web Apps
body:
### Code sample

_No response_

### MDN URL:

_No response_

### Specification URL:

https://github.com/WICG/isolated-web-apps

### Any other links?

https://chromestatus.com/feature/5146307550248960

### How stable is this feature?

Future (No implementations yet)

### Type of feature

Other

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Security & Privacy, Bridging the gap with native

### Details

Isolated Web Apps is related to [Subresource Integrity](https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/145) and [PWA manifest](https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/119). It provides a missing security layer that native apps have, which is signed updates to the app. A notable example is [Signal's refusal](https://github.com/WICG/isolated-web-apps/blob/64ee186/README.md?plain=1#L11) to implement a web version of their app due to this missing piece. It would be interesting to see if other developers also avoid building web apps due to this.

title: Shadow DOM
body:
Encapsulate elements not visible from the outside, and style them with CSS not affecting the rest of the page.

### Code sample

```html
this.shadowRoot = this.attachShadow({mode: "open"});
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_components/Using_shadow_DOM

### Specification URL:

_No response_

### Any other links?

_No response_

### How stable is this feature?

Stable (Widely supported for several years)

### Type of feature

JS API

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Making Web Components

### Details

We should probably ask about Shadow DOM as a whole too.

title: `<iframe seamless>`
body:
Makes an iframe's contents part of a page, adopting styles from its hosting page

### Code sample

```html

```


### MDN URL:

_No response_

https://www.w3.org/TR/2011/WD-html5-20110525/the-iframe-element.html#attr-iframe-seamless

### How stable is this feature?

Removed (No longer supported in any major browsers)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Embedding

### Details

@chrishtr mentioned this as a feature he is interested in getting data about, however, it's a feature that has been removed from the Web Platform. Is it disingenuous to ask about removed features? ðŸ¤”

title: Window Controls Overlay API
body:
Allows PWAs to display custom content over the title bar area, whose controls become an overlay.

### Code sample


### How stable is this feature?

Cutting edge (Shipped, but not in all browsers)

### Type of feature

JS API, CSS, Other

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Bridging the gap with native

### Details

Alternatively, if we have a question about manifest fields, we could ask about this by asking about `display_override: "window-controls-overlay"`. Though then we'd have to pick between usage and awareness.

title: Tab/Spicy Sections
body:
### Code sample ```html

Tabs

The tab-bar affordance can use shadow-dom to establish a styleable tab-bar and panels. The required parts can be exposed for styling with consistent pseudo-elements.

In a tab state, we likely want to style:

  • The outer box
  • The tab bar
  • The tabs themselves
  • The selected tab
  • The tab panel area

Collapse

The accordion-like collapse affordance also uses shadow-dom to establish summary-details like behavior for each section, with an option to make the toggle-states exclusive-collapse.

In an accordion state, we likely want to style:

  • The outer box
  • The section headings/buttons
  • The open/closed marker
  • Open and closed heading styles
  • Open and closed content styles

Structured Content

The fallback state is simply structured HTML, without any show/hide affordances. This does not require any special styling.

``` ### MDN URL: _No response_ ### Specification URL: https://css-tricks.com/newsletter/281-tabs-and-spicy-drama/#:~:text=Except%20so%20far%20they%E2%80%99ve%20come%20to%20the%20conclusion,component%20based%20on%20the%20width%20of%20the%20browser. ### Any other links? https://daverupert.com/2021/10/native-html-tabs/ ### How stable is this feature? Future (No implementations yet) ### Type of feature HTML element ### What focus area does this feature fall under? _No response_ ### Details _No response_

The `<model>` element allows embedding 3D graphical content into an HTML page.

title: Defining slots (`<slot>` and `::slotted()`)
body:

Making Web Components ### Other details We may want to separate `` and `::slotted()`.

title: `ElementInternals` API
body:
Assign hidden semantics to custom elements, facilitating accessibility and allowing them to participate fully in forms.

```js
this.#internals = this.attachInternals()
this.#internals.ariaChecked = true;
```

Making Web Components

title: Structured data (RDFa, Microdata, Microformats)
body:
Technologies for embedding machine-readable data in HTML.

```html
<!-- RDFa: -->
<time property="datePublished" datetime="2009-05-08">May 8, 2009</time>

<!-- Microdata: -->
<time itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2009-05-08">May 8, 2009</time>

<!-- Microformats: -->
<time class="dt-published" datetime="2009-05-08">May 8, 2009</time>
```

### URLs:

- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Microdata
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/microformats
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RDFa
- https://almanac.httparchive.org/en/2022/structured-data

### How stable is this feature?

Stable (Widely supported for several years)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute, HTML attribute value

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Semantic HTML

### Details

We might want a separate, multiple choice, question: 

**Have you used any types of Structured data in HTML?**
- [ ] RDFa
- [ ] Microdata
- [ ] Microformats
- [ ] None

title: Extended built-ins
body:
Extend built-in elements with custom behavior.

```html
<button is="primary-button">Continue</button>
<script>
	customElements.define("primary-button", PrimaryButton, {extends: "button"});
</script>
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/is

### Specification URL:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/custom-elements.html#attr-is

### Any other links?

- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CustomElementRegistry/define
- [WebKit Standards Position](https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/97)

### How stable is this feature?

Controversial (Some implementations that have existed for years, other browsers have declined to implement)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute, JS API

### What focus area does this feature fall into?

Consuming Web Components, Making Web Components

### Details

We could ask about the `is` attribute and `customElementRegistry.define("tagname", Class, {extends})` separately if we want to distinguish consumption from usage.
For now, Iâ€™ve included them in the same item.

title: HTML Modules
Exclusive accordion
body:
Group `<details>` elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.

### Code sample

```html
<details open name="sidebar_panel" id="main_info">
	<summary>Main info</summary>
	<!-- controls -->
</details>
<details open name="sidebar_panel" id="style_settings">
	<summary>Style</summary>
	<!-- controls -->
</details>
```


### MDN URL:

_No response_

### Specification URL:

https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9400

### Any other links?

- [TAG review](https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/866#issuecomment-1661272254)
- [Open UI Exploration](https://open-ui.org/components/accordion.explainer/)
- [Chrome Status](https://chromestatus.com/feature/6710427028815872)

### How stable is this feature?

Future (No implementations yet)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Interactivity

### Details

The `name` attribute groups creates groups of `<details>` elements, where opening one closes the others, allowing easier implementation of accordions.

title: `<template>`
body: A mechanism for holding HTML that is not to be rendered immediately but may be utilized later via JS. ```html ``` ### MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/template ### Specification URL: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/scripting.html#the-template-element ### Any other links? _No response_ ### How stable is this feature? Stable (Has been widely supported for several years) ### Type of feature HTML element ### What focus area does this feature fall into? Templating ### Details More specific use cases for `

title: Imperative slot assignment
body:
A way to assign elements to slots manually via JS, so that slot assignment does not have to be managed by the component consumers.

```js
this.attachShadow({mode: "open", slotAssignment: "manual" });
this.shadowRoot.querySelector("slot[name=foo]").assign(element);
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLSlotElement/assign

### Specification URL:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/scripting.html#dom-slot-assign

### Any other links?

https://caniuse.com/mdn-api_shadowroot_slotassignment

### How stable is this feature?

Recent (Enabled by default in all major browsers)

### Type of feature

JS API

### What focus area does this feature fall into?

Making Web Components

### Details

_No response_

title: Form validation
body:
Set of HTML attributes and JS APIs to facilitate client-side form validation (`<input pattern>`, `<input required>`, `input. setCustomValidity(msg)` etc)

```html
<input id="zip" pattern="[0-9]{5}" title="5 digits" required />
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Forms/Form_validation

### Specification URL:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/form-control-infrastructure.html#the-constraint-validation-api

### Any other links?

_No response_

### How stable is this feature?

title: ARIA
body:
Attributes to make markup more accessible (`role`, `aria-label`, `aria-haspopup` etc). ```html
Prices
``` ### MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA ### Specification URL: https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.2/ ### Any other links? https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Attributes ### How stable is this feature? Stable (Widely supported for several years) ### Type of feature HTML attribute ### What focus area does this feature fall into? Accessibility ### Details ARIA as a whole, including `role` and all the `aria-*` attributes. Do we want to break this down? If so, how? See also, [this discussion](https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/115).

title: Resource Hints: preconnect (`<link rel=preconnect>`)
body:
Speed up future loads from a given origin by preemptively performing part or all of the DNS+TCP+TLS handshake.

```html
<link rel="preconnect" href="(url)" />
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/rel/preconnect

### Specification URL:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/links.html#link-type-preconnect

### Any other links?

https://caniuse.com/link-rel-preconnect

### How stable is this feature?

Recent (Shipped in all major browsers)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute value

### What focus area does this feature fall into?

Performance

### Details

Alternatively, we may opt to ask about Resource Hints in general, see https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/109

title: Resource Hints: prerender (`<link rel=prerender>`)
body:
A hint to browsers that the user might need the target resource for the next navigation

```html
<link rel="prerender" href="(url)" />
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/rel/prerender

### Specification URL:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/links.html#link-type-prerender

### Any other links?

https://caniuse.com/link-rel-prerender

### How stable is this feature?

Deprecated (Still supported, but not recommended for use in new projects)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute value

### What focus area does this feature fall into?

Performance

### Details

Alternatively, we may opt to ask about Resource Hints in general, see https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/109

title: Resource Hints: preload (`<link rel=preload>`)
body:
Start loading certain resources early in the page lifecycle.

```html
<link rel="preload" href="(url)" />
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/rel/preload

### Specification URL:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/links.html#link-type-preload

### Any other links?

https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2016/02/preload-what-is-it-good-for/

### How stable is this feature?

Recent (Shipped in all major browsers)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute value

### What focus area does this feature fall into?

Performance

### Details

Alternatively, we may opt to ask about Resource Hints in general, see https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/109

title: Resource Hints (all)
body:
Begin work on certain resources earlier to improve performance.

```html
<link rel="preconnect" href="(url)" />
<link rel="prerender" href="(url)" />
<link rel="preload" href="(url)" />
<link rel="prefetch" href="(url)" />
<link rel="dns-prefetch" href="(url)" />
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Performance/Web_Performance_Basics

### Specification URL:

_No response_

### Any other links?

https://blog.logrocket.com/understanding-css-preload-other-resource-hints/
https://medium.com/@luisvieira_gmr/html5-prefetch-1e54f6dda15d

### How stable is this feature?

Cutting edge (Shipped, but not in all browsers)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute value

### What focus area does this feature fall into?

Performance

### Details

There are already suggestions for asking about these separately:
- https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/104
- https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/105
- https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/106
- https://github.com/Devographics/surveys/discussions/107

However, we may instead want to ask about them all together, to reduce number of questions.

title: Declarative Shadow DOM (`<template shadowrootmode="open">`)
body:
Define shadow trees with HTML.

### Code sample

```html
<host-element>
    <template shadowrootmode="open">
        <!-- Shadow content -->
    </template>
</host-element>
```

Cutting edge (Some implementations but not in all browsers and/or behind flags)

HTML attribute

Making Web Components

### Details

A way to implement and use Shadow DOM directly in HTML.

title: Subresource Integrity (`integrity` attribute)
body:
A security feature to verify that fetched resources have not been tampered with.

### Code sample

```html
<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.js" crossorigin
 integrity="sha384-q8i/X+965DzO0Kp4H+8aPi6jizo"></script>
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Subresource_Integrity

title: Exposing component parts (`part` attribute)
body:
Expose Shadow DOM elements to be stylable by component consumers.

### Code sample

```html
this.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `
<input id="url" part="input location">`;
```

Stable (Widely supported for several years)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Making Web Components

### Details

Defining parts so that consumers can style them via CSS (using `::part()`)

title: Styling component parts (`::part()`)
body:
A way to style shadow DOM elements that have opted in to being stylable from the outside.

### Code sample

```css
fancy-loader::part(loaded-bar) {
  background: var(--accent-color);
}
```


### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/::part

### Specification URL:

https://www.w3.org/TR/css-shadow-parts-1/#part

_No response_

_No response_

title: Navigation API
Defining Custom Elements
body:
Defining custom elements for use by others.
If you have never used this, you can probably skip the rest of this section.


This question needs to be the first in the "Making Web Components" section.

title: Fetch Priority API (`fetchpriority` attribute)
body: Allows specifying a hint to help the browser prioritize fetching various resources. ### Code sample ```html ``` ### MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/fetchPriority ### Specification URL: https://wicg.github.io/priority-hints/ ### Any other links? - [Can I Use ``](https://caniuse.com/mdn-html_elements_img_fetchpriority) - [Can I Use ``](https://caniuse.com/mdn-html_elements_link_fetchpriority) - [Can I Use `

title: `autocomplete="hint"`
body:
Provide hints about what kind of information should be autocompleted.

### Code sample

```html
<input name="first_name" autocomplete="given-name" />
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/autocomplete

### Specification URL:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/form-control-infrastructure.html#attr-fe-autocomplete

### Any other links?

_No response_

### How stable is this feature?

Mixed (Some parts stable, others unimplemented or inconsistent)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute value

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Forms

### Details

Browsers seem wildly inconsistent with their support for auto-completion, and I think this is one of the primary factors towards devs not using it.

Some browsers may honor auto-completion rules, others will completely ignore it, and others still will guess their own auto-completion putting the wrong values in the wrong place even when the page's source code explicitly says to disable all auto-completion.

It's worth asking about form auto-completion because everyone seems to be confused about how it works in practice, causing many developers to refrain from using it.

body:
Attribute to make an element and its descendants non-interactive, and invisible to assistive technology. ### Code sample ```html

title: input `pattern` attribute
body:
### Code sample

```html
<label for="username">Username: (3-16 characters)</label>
<input name="username" type="text" value="Sasha" pattern="\w{3,16}" required>

<label for="pin">PIN: (4 digits)</label>
<input name="pin" type="password" pattern="\d{4,4}" required>
```


### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/pattern

### Specification URL:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/input.html#attr-input-pattern

### Any other links?

https://caniuse.com/input-pattern

### How stable is this feature?

Stable (Widely supported for several years)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Forms

### Details

This is an attribute that seems like it would be really useful, but I don't recall ever seeing it outside of blog posts, it could be interesting to see if this is just due to a lack of knowledge about the attribute or something else that might be missing from it

Forms

### Details

(the spec existed at one point, but I couldn't find a way to get a proper link to it at the time, I can change the url if there's a way to get it)

Yeah... so [whu happen](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tAN2TYUGEPk) ?

This one always seemed like it would've been a _really_ useful feature, but I never saw anything about it online, no one implemented it, and then it was dropped.

I wonder if it was due to lack of general knowledge about the attribute even being proposed in the first place (lea's blog post is the only time I ever saw anything about it), or if it actually wasn't meant to be for poor ol' range multiple

title: HTTP client hints
body:
```http
Accept-CH: Width, Downlink, Sec-CH-UA
```

### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Client_hints

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-grigorik-http-client-hints

Cutting edge (Shipped, but not in all browsers)

HTTP

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Other

title: Adaptive streaming
body:
### Code sample

```html
<video>
  <source src="movie.mpd" />
  <source src="movie.webm" />
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>
```


### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/DASH_Adaptive_Streaming_for_HTML_5_Video

### Specification URL:

http://wiki.webmproject.org/adaptive-streaming/webm-dash-specification

### Any other links?

- [Can I Use: MPEG DASH](https://caniuse.com/mpeg-dash)
- [Can I Use: HTTP Live Streaming](https://caniuse.com/http-live-streaming)
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/Audio_and_video_delivery/Setting_up_adaptive_streaming_media_sources
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/Audio_and_video_delivery/Live_streaming_web_audio_and_video

### How stable is this feature?

Future (No implementations yet)

### Type of feature

Other

### What focus area does this feature fall under?

Multimedia

### Details

_No response_

title: `exportparts` attribute
body:
### Code sample

```html
<!-- In Shadow DOM: -->
<img-input exportparts="dropzone: img-input-dropzone"></img-input>
```


### MDN URL:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/exportparts

### Specification URL:

https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shadow-parts/#element-attrdef-html-global-exportparts

### Any other links?

[Can I Use](https://caniuse.com/mdn-html_global_attributes_exportparts)

### How stable is this feature?

Stable (Widely supported for several years)

### Type of feature

HTML attribute

### What focus area does this feature fall into?

Consuming Web Components, Making Web Components

### Details

Export parts of Shadow DOM components as parts of the consuming component so they can be styled by authors of that via `::part()`.
